task_1.query_used: Search LinkedIn for Ali Khaledi Nasab artificial intelligence researcher profile and current employment
task_1.data:
Dr. Ali Khaledi-Nasab is a physicist and artificial intelligence (AI) scientist currently working at Amazon Rufus. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D. After completing his doctoral studies, Dr. Khaledi-Nasab held a research position at Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery, focusing on developing stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders, including Parkinson's disease. He later joined CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup targeting epilepsy treatments. Following the closure of CODA in 2022 due to funding challenges, he transitioned to Amazon, where he has been involved in generative AI projects since 2023. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his industry roles, Dr. Khaledi-Nasab has contributed to academia as an adjunct professor of physics at Ohio University. His research interests encompass machine learning, AI, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics. He has authored several publications in these areas, reflecting his interdisciplinary expertise. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Dr. Khaledi-Nasab is also known for his commitment to continuous learning, dedicating time daily to reading and taking courses. He aligns with Amazon's leadership principle of "Learn and Be Curious," emphasizing the importance of ongoing personal and professional development. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

task_2.query_used: Search Google Scholar and ResearchGate for academic publications by Ali Khaledi Nasab in AI field
task_2.data:
Ali Khaledi-Nasab is a researcher with a diverse academic background, having contributed to various fields including nanotechnology, nonlinear dynamics, and computational neuroscience. His work encompasses both experimental and theoretical studies, reflecting a multidisciplinary approach to scientific inquiry.

In the realm of nanotechnology, Khaledi-Nasab has co-authored studies on the synthesis and characterization of nanoparticles. For instance, he contributed to research on the green synthesis of ZnO nanoparticles using potato extract, highlighting their potential applications in various fields. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

In the field of nonlinear dynamics, Khaledi-Nasab has explored the collective behavior of excitable elements in tree networks. His work includes studies on emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in such networks, providing insights into the dynamics of complex systems. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Additionally, Khaledi-Nasab has been involved in research related to the impact of coordinated reset stimulation on neuronal networks, contributing to the understanding of desynchronization effects in plastic neural networks. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

His academic contributions are accessible through platforms like Google Scholar, where his publications are listed. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Overall, Khaledi-Nasab's interdisciplinary research has provided valuable insights into the synthesis of nanomaterials and the dynamics of complex systems, contributing to advancements in both theoretical and applied sciences.

task_3.query_used: Search IEEE Xplore and ACM Digital Library for research papers authored by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_3.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab has authored several research papers across various fields, including physics, neuroscience, and social sciences. Below is a summary of some of his notable works:

1. **"Standing up to fear"** (2017): In this article, Khaledi Nasab reflects on the challenges faced by international students in the U.S. following the 2017 travel ban. He discusses the climate of fear and uncertainty, emphasizing the need for institutional support for immigrant scientists. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

2. **"Information processing in tree networks of excitable elements"** (2021): This study examines the collective response of small random tree networks of diffusively coupled excitable elements, contributing to the understanding of complex systems in physics. ([stanford.academia.edu](https://stanford.academia.edu/AliKhalediNasab?swp=tc-au-6993172&utm_source=openai))

3. **"Long-Lasting Desynchronization Effects of Coordinated Reset Stimulation Improved by Random Jitters"** (2021): Co-authored with J. A. Kromer and P. A. Tass, this paper investigates the impact of coordinated reset stimulation on neural networks, with potential applications in treating neurological disorders. ([stanford.academia.edu](https://stanford.academia.edu/AliKhalediNasab?swp=tc-au-6993172&utm_source=openai))

4. **"Variability of collective dynamics in random tree networks of strongly coupled stochastic excitable elements"** (2018): This research delves into the collective dynamics of strongly coupled excitable elements on small random tree networks, offering insights into stochastic processes in complex systems. ([stanford.academia.edu](https://stanford.academia.edu/AliKhalediNasab?swp=tc-au-6993172&utm_source=openai))

5. **"Kerr nonlinearity due to intersubband transitions in a three-level InAs/GaAs quantum dot: the impact of a wetting layer on dispersion curves"** (2014): Co-authored with M. Sabaeian, M. Sahrai, and V. Fallahi, this paper explores the Kerr nonlinearity in quantum dots, focusing on the effects of a wetting layer on dispersion curves. ([stanford.academia.edu](https://stanford.academia.edu/AliKhalediNasab?swp=tc-au-6993172&utm_source=openai))

These publications highlight Khaledi Nasab's interdisciplinary research contributions, spanning from theoretical physics to neuroscience and social issues.

task_4.query_used: Search GitHub and GitLab for code repositories and AI projects by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_4.data:
I searched GitHub and GitLab for code repositories and AI projects associated with Ali Khaledi Nasab but did not find any direct matches. However, I found information about an individual named Ali Khaledi-Nasab, a post-doctoral researcher affiliated with Amazon in Seattle, United States. His research interests include machine learning, artificial intelligence, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics. ([loop.frontiersin.org](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/bio?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, there is a GitHub user named Seyed Ali Khalili (@imseyed) who has repositories related to data mining, IoT, machine learning, and communication. While the username is similar, there is no direct evidence linking this individual to Ali Khaledi Nasab. ([github.com](https://github.com/imseyed?utm_source=openai))

Furthermore, Ali Khaledi-Nasab has an academic profile on Google Scholar, indicating a background in physics and astronomy, with publications in areas such as quantum dots and nonlinear dynamics. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Given the commonality of the name, it's possible that the GitHub user @imseyed is a different individual. Without more specific information, I cannot confirm a direct connection between Ali Khaledi Nasab and the GitHub repositories.

task_5.query_used: Search university faculty directories and research institution websites for Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_5.data:
Dr. Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon Rufus. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D. After completing his doctoral studies, he joined Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery as a research scientist, focusing on developing stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders, including Parkinson's disease. In 2021, he transitioned to CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup targeting epilepsy treatments. Following the closure of CODA in 2022 due to funding challenges, Dr. Khaledi Nasab joined Amazon as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity team. In 2024, he moved to Amazon Rufus to work on their latest Generative AI product. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Throughout his career, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has contributed to various research projects. While at Stanford, he co-authored several publications, including:

- "Long-lasting desynchronization of plastic neuronal networks by double-random coordinated reset stimulation" in *Frontiers in Network Physiology* (2022).

- "Dynamics of oscillatory neuronal networks with synaptic weight and structural plasticity" in *Scientific Reports* (2022).

These works explore the dynamics of neuronal networks and their potential applications in treating neurological conditions. ([med.stanford.edu](https://med.stanford.edu/tass-lab/publications.html?utm_source=openai))

Prior to his time at Stanford, Dr. Khaledi Nasab completed his Ph.D. at Ohio University, where he focused on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks. His research aimed to understand the functioning and information processing in sensory neurons with tree-like structures. He presented his findings at various conferences, including the American Physical Society meeting in 2019. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his professional achievements, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has been recognized for his contributions to science communication. In 2023, he published an article in *Science* magazine titled "I almost sold a kidney to pursue my PhD," reflecting on the financial challenges faced by international students pursuing higher education. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Dr. Khaledi Nasab's diverse background in physics, neuroscience, and AI underscores his commitment to advancing our understanding of complex systems and developing innovative solutions for neurological disorders.

citations.title: Publications | Peter Tass Lab | Stanford Medicine
Khaledi Nasab Receives APS Travel Award to Attend Conference - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences

task_6.query_used: Search AI conference proceedings and speaker lists for presentations by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_6.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist whose research has spanned various interdisciplinary fields, including nonlinear dynamics, computational neuroscience, and artificial intelligence. His work has been presented at several conferences and has contributed to multiple publications.

**Conference Presentations:**

- **2017 Colloquium at the College of Wooster:** On October 3, 2017, Nasab delivered a colloquium titled "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements" at the Department of Physics at the College of Wooster. His research focused on the stochastic dynamics of tree networks of excitable elements, relevant to certain sensory neurons, such as those in cat muscle spindles. The study aimed to predict the spontaneous activity of these networks by analyzing a single effective node with scaled parameters and suggested mechanisms for tuning the activity of the central element in the tree network. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

- **2019 APS Meeting Presentation:** In March 2019, Nasab presented his paper "Dynamics of excitable tree networks: Application to sensory neurons" at the annual meeting of the American Physical Society (APS) in Boston. His research delved into the dynamical principles of functioning and information processing in sensory neurons with tree-like morphologies of their myelinated terminals, such as those found in muscle spindles, pain receptors, mechanoreceptors, and electroreceptors. The study utilized theoretical and computational approaches to understand mechanisms of spike generation and information coding in these neurons. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

**Publications:**

Nasab has authored and co-authored several publications, including:

- "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements"

- "Variability of collective dynamics in random tree networks of strongly coupled stochastic excitable elements"

- "Information processing in tree networks of excitable elements"

These works explore the collective dynamics and information processing mechanisms in networks of excitable elements, contributing to the understanding of complex systems in neuroscience. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

For a comprehensive overview of his research and publications, you can visit his personal website. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

task_7.query_used: Search corporate filings and business registries for companies associated with Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_7.data:
Based on the available information, there is no direct evidence linking an individual named Ali Khaledi Nasab to specific corporate filings or business registries. However, a search for similar names reveals individuals with the surname "Kharazmi" involved in business activities.

For instance, in the 2016 10-K filing of NuGene International, Inc., the company's Chairman of the Board is Mohammad Ali Kharazmi, and the Acting Chief Financial Officer and Board Member is Mohammad Saeed Kharazmi. The filing discusses a lawsuit involving Advanced Surgical Partners, LLC, which names NuGene, Inc., and the Kharazmi brothers as defendants. ([sec.gov](https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1593549/000161577417001634/s105503_10k.htm?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, the 2006 S-1 filing for U.S. Auto Parts Network, Inc. mentions individuals named Khazani, Nia, and Elyashar, who are associated with the company and its subsidiaries. While the surname differs, the phonetic similarity to "Kharazmi" is notable. ([sec.gov](https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1378950/000119312506221797/ds1.htm?utm_source=openai))

It's important to note that "Kharazmi" is a common surname in Iran, and individuals with this name are involved in various business activities. However, without more specific information, it's challenging to establish a direct connection to an individual named Ali Khaledi Nasab.

task_9.query_used: Search news articles and press releases mentioning Ali Khaledi Nasab in AI research context
task_9.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist whose research focuses on the dynamics of excitable tree networks, particularly in sensory neurons with tree-like structures. His work aims to understand the principles of functioning and information processing in these neurons, which are crucial for various sensory functions.

In 2019, Khaledi Nasab received the American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award. This grant supported his attendance at the annual APS meeting in Boston, where he presented his paper titled "Dynamics of excitable tree networks: Application to sensory neurons." His research utilized theoretical and computational approaches to explore mechanisms of spike generation and information coding in sensory neurons with tree-like myelinated terminals. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

In 2017, he was invited to give a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster's Department of Physics. His presentation, "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements," delved into the stochastic dynamics of tree networks of excitable elements, relevant to sensory neurons like cat muscle spindles. The study suggested that the spontaneous activity of these networks could be predicted by examining a single effective node with scaled parameters, offering insights into tuning the activity of central elements in tree networks. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, in 2017, Khaledi Nasab shared his experiences as an international student in the United States in a column titled "Standing up to fear" published in the journal Science. He discussed the challenges faced by international students, particularly in light of the travel ban implemented by the Trump administration, and emphasized the importance of institutional support for international scholars. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

These contributions highlight Khaledi Nasab's dedication to advancing our understanding of sensory neuron dynamics and his active engagement in the scientific community.

task_10.query_used: Search professional networking sites and AI industry forums for Ali Khaledi Nasab mentions
task_10.data:
Ali Khaledi-Nasab is an academic researcher who has contributed to several studies in the fields of physics and software engineering. Notably, he co-authored a paper titled "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge," which explores mechanisms to reduce polarization in social networks by introducing random inputs to users' opinions. ([export.arxiv.org](https://export.arxiv.org/abs/2101.04079?utm_source=openai))

In the software engineering domain, Khaledi-Nasab collaborated on research that involved classifying Stack Overflow posts using machine learning techniques to support software architectural knowledge management. ([onlinelibrary.wiley.com](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpe.6277?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, he co-authored a study titled "Mining Q&A Platforms for Empirical Evidence on Quantum Software Programming," which analyzes discussions on Stack Exchange platforms to identify key topics and challenges in quantum software development. ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/html/2503.05240v1?utm_source=openai))

These publications highlight Khaledi-Nasab's interdisciplinary research interests, spanning social network dynamics and software engineering.

task_11.query_used: Search ORCID and academic identifier databases for Ali Khaledi Nasab research profile
task_11.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist with a diverse academic and professional background. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D. He completed his doctoral studies in Physics and Astronomy at Ohio University, focusing on the dynamics of excitable tree networks in sensory neurons. His research aimed to understand the functioning and information processing in these neurons, which have a tree-like morphology of their myelinated terminals. This work was supervised by Dr. Alexander Neiman, a Professor of Physics at Ohio University. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

After earning his Ph.D., Khaledi Nasab joined the Department of Neurosurgery at Stanford University School of Medicine as a research scientist. There, he worked on developing stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders, including Parkinson's disease. One of the techniques he contributed to is Coordinated Reset (CR) stimulation, which aims to counteract abnormal synchronization in neural networks. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

In 2022, he transitioned to Amazon, where he currently serves as a research scientist in the Network Capacity Planning organization. His work at Amazon focuses on applying his expertise in physics and AI to enhance network performance and capacity. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

Throughout his career, Khaledi Nasab has been involved in various research projects and has contributed to publications in the fields of physics, neuroscience, and AI. His interdisciplinary approach combines principles from nonlinear dynamics, stochastic processes, signal processing, statistics, biophysics, and network sciences. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, he has been active in addressing social issues, such as advocating for international students during the 2017 U.S. travel ban. He authored an article titled "Standing up to fear," published in Science magazine, reflecting on the challenges faced by international students in the U.S. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

For a comprehensive overview of his work and publications, you can visit his personal website. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon Rufus. He holds a Ph.D. in Physics and has a diverse background in physics, neuroscience, and AI. His professional journey includes positions at Stanford University School of Medicine's Department of Neurosurgery and CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup. In 2022, he joined Amazon as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity team. In 2024, he transitioned to Amazon Rufus to work on their latest Generative AI product. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Regarding his presence on social media platforms like Twitter and Facebook, there is no publicly available information indicating that Ali Khaledi Nasab maintains official accounts on these platforms. While there are individuals with similar names on Twitter, such as @hoalimadad, @AliKhalesi8, and @AliKhalesi1, there is no evidence to suggest that these accounts are associated with him. ([idcrawl.com](https://www.idcrawl.com/ali-khalesi?utm_source=openai))

In 2017, Ali Khaledi Nasab authored an article titled "Standing up to fear," published in the journal *Science*. In this piece, he reflects on the challenges faced by international students in the U.S. following the implementation of the travel ban. He discusses the uncertainty and fear experienced by international students and emphasizes the need for institutional support during such times. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

For more detailed information about his professional background and research, you can visit his personal website. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

report:
## OSINT Intelligence Report: Ali Khaledi Nasab

**Report Date:** June 11, 2025

### Executive Summary

Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently employed at Amazon Rufus, working on Generative AI. He has a diverse background spanning nanotechnology, neuroscience, and AI, with experience at Stanford and CODA Biotherapeutics. No immediate red flags were identified.


### Thematic Summary of Key Findings

**Professional / Career Background**

* Currently employed at Amazon Rufus, working on Generative AI (2024-Present).
* Research Scientist at Amazon in the AWS network capacity team (2022-2024).
* Researcher at Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery, focusing on neurological disorder treatments (Dates unspecified).
* Worked at CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on epilepsy treatments. CODA closed in 2022 due to funding challenges.
* Post-doctoral researcher (Affiliation not specified).

**Business & Financial Activity**

* No direct business affiliations or financial activities were identified besides employment history.

**Legal or Criminal Mentions**

* No mentions of legal or criminal activity were found.

**Academic / Public Recognition**

* Ph.D. in Physics and Astronomy from Ohio University. Dissertation focused on the dynamics of excitable tree networks in sensory neurons under the supervision of Dr. Alexander Neiman.
* Presented research at the College of Wooster in 2017 on "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements."
* Received an APS travel award to attend a conference in 2019.
* Authored and co-authored several research papers across physics, neuroscience, social sciences, and software engineering, including publications on nanotechnology, depolarization of echo chambers, and classifying Stack Overflow posts.

**Online / Social Presence**

* Maintains a personal website: alikhaledi.com.
* Profile mentioned on Frontiers Loop: [https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/bio](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/bio?utm_source=openai)
* Academia.edu profile: [https://stanford.academia.edu/AliKhalediNasab](https://stanford.academia.edu/AliKhalediNasab?swp=tc-au-6993172&utm_source=openai)
* Google Scholar profile: [https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai)


**Other Notable Mentions**

* Moved from Iran to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D.
* Wrote an article titled "Standing up to fear" in 2017, reflecting on challenges faced by international students after the 2017 travel ban.


### Risk Profile

Based on the available information, Ali Khaledi Nasab presents a **low reputational risk**.  He has a consistent and verifiable academic and professional background with no indications of legal issues or controversies.

judgement.revised_report:
## OSINT Intelligence Report: Ali Khaledi Nasab

**Report Date:** June 11, 2025

### Executive Summary

Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently employed at Amazon Rufus, working on Generative AI (2024-Present)¹. He has a diverse background spanning nanotechnology, neuroscience, and AI, with experience at Stanford University School of Medicine and CODA Biotherapeutics. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D. No immediate red flags were identified.

### Thematic Summary of Key Findings

**Professional / Career Background**

* Currently employed at Amazon Rufus, working on Generative AI (2024-Present)¹
* Research Scientist at Amazon in the AWS network capacity team (2022-2024)¹¹
* Research Scientist at Stanford University School of Medicine's Department of Neurosurgery (post-Ph.D.), focusing on developing stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders including Parkinson's disease¹¹
* Worked at CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on epilepsy treatments. CODA closed in 2022 due to funding challenges¹
* Adjunct Professor of Physics at Ohio University¹

**Business & Financial Activity**

* No direct business affiliations or financial activities were identified besides employment history
* No corporate filings or business registries found under his name⁷

**Legal or Criminal Mentions**

* No mentions of legal or criminal activity were found

**Academic / Public Recognition**

* Ph.D. in Physics and Astronomy from Ohio University, with dissertation focusing on "the dynamics of excitable tree networks in sensory neurons" under the supervision of Dr. Alexander Neiman¹¹
* Presented "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements" at the College of Wooster in 2017⁶
* Presented "Dynamics of excitable tree networks: Application to sensory neurons" at the 2019 APS Meeting in Boston⁶
* Received an APS travel award to attend the 2019 conference⁶
* Authored and co-authored several interdisciplinary research papers including:
  - "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge" (exploring social network polarization)¹⁰
  - "Mining Q&A Platforms for Empirical Evidence on Quantum Software Programming"¹⁰
  - Multiple papers on nanotechnology, including green synthesis of ZnO nanoparticles²
  - Studies on coordinated reset stimulation in neural networks³
  - "Standing up to fear" (2017) - an article in Science magazine reflecting on challenges faced by international students after the 2017 travel ban³,¹¹

**Online / Social Presence**

* Maintains a personal website: alikhaledi.com¹,¹¹
* Profile on Frontiers Loop: https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/bio⁴
* Academia.edu profile: https://stanford.academia.edu/AliKhalediNasab³
* Google Scholar profile: https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ¹,²
* No verified social media accounts on Twitter or Facebook were found¹²

**Other Notable Mentions**

* Moved from Iran to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D.¹,¹¹
* Known for commitment to continuous learning, aligning with Amazon's "Learn and Be Curious" principle¹
* Research interests encompass machine learning, AI, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics⁴
* No AI-related patents found in USPTO or Google Patents databases⁸
* No code repositories found on GitHub or GitLab directly linked to him⁴

### Risk Profile

Based on the available information, Ali Khaledi Nasab presents a **low reputational risk**. task_1.query_used: Search LinkedIn for Ali Khaledi Nasab artificial intelligence researcher profile and current employment
task_1.data:
Dr. Ali Khaledi-Nasab is a physicist and artificial intelligence (AI) scientist currently working at Amazon Rufus. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D. After completing his doctoral studies, Dr. Khaledi-Nasab held a research position at Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery, focusing on developing stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders, including Parkinson's disease. He later joined CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup targeting epilepsy treatments. Following the closure of CODA in 2022 due to funding challenges, he transitioned to Amazon, where he has been involved in generative AI projects since 2023. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his industry roles, Dr. Khaledi-Nasab has contributed to academia as an adjunct professor of physics at Ohio University. His research interests encompass machine learning, AI, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics. He has authored several publications in these areas, reflecting his interdisciplinary expertise. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Dr. Khaledi-Nasab is also known for his commitment to continuous learning, dedicating time daily to reading and taking courses. He aligns with Amazon's leadership principle of "Learn and Be Curious," emphasizing the importance of ongoing personal and professional development. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

task_2.query_used: Search Google Scholar and ResearchGate for academic publications by Ali Khaledi Nasab in AI field
task_2.data:
Ali Khaledi-Nasab is a researcher with a diverse academic background, having contributed to various fields including nanotechnology, nonlinear dynamics, and computational neuroscience. His work encompasses both experimental and theoretical studies, reflecting a multidisciplinary approach to scientific inquiry.

In the realm of nanotechnology, Khaledi-Nasab has co-authored studies on the synthesis and characterization of nanoparticles. For instance, he contributed to research on the green synthesis of ZnO nanoparticles using potato extract, highlighting their potential applications in various fields. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

In the field of nonlinear dynamics, Khaledi-Nasab has explored the collective behavior of excitable elements in tree networks. His work includes studies on emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in such networks, providing insights into the dynamics of complex systems. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Additionally, Khaledi-Nasab has been involved in research related to the impact of coordinated reset stimulation on neuronal networks, contributing to the understanding of desynchronization effects in plastic neural networks. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

His academic contributions are accessible through platforms like Google Scholar, where his publications are listed. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Overall, Khaledi-Nasab's interdisciplinary research has provided valuable insights into the synthesis of nanomaterials and the dynamics of complex systems, contributing to advancements in both theoretical and applied sciences.

task_3.query_used: Search IEEE Xplore and ACM Digital Library for research papers authored by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_3.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab has authored several research papers across various fields, including physics, neuroscience, and social sciences. Below is a summary of some of his notable works:

1. **"Standing up to fear"** (2017): In this article, Khaledi Nasab reflects on the challenges faced by international students in the U.S. following the 2017 travel ban. He discusses the climate of fear and uncertainty, emphasizing the need for institutional support for immigrant scientists. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

2. **"Information processing in tree networks of excitable elements"** (2021): This study examines the collective response of small random tree networks of diffusively coupled excitable elements, contributing to the understanding of complex systems in physics. ([stanford.academia.edu](https://stanford.academia.edu/AliKhalediNasab?swp=tc-au-6993172&utm_source=openai))

3. **"Long-Lasting Desynchronization Effects of Coordinated Reset Stimulation Improved by Random Jitters"** (2021): Co-authored with J. A. Kromer and P. A. Tass, this paper investigates the impact of coordinated reset stimulation on neural networks, with potential applications in treating neurological disorders. ([stanford.academia.edu](https://stanford.academia.edu/AliKhalediNasab?swp=tc-au-6993172&utm_source=openai))

4. **"Variability of collective dynamics in random tree networks of strongly coupled stochastic excitable elements"** (2018): This research delves into the collective dynamics of strongly coupled excitable elements on small random tree networks, offering insights into stochastic processes in complex systems. ([stanford.academia.edu](https://stanford.academia.edu/AliKhalediNasab?swp=tc-au-6993172&utm_source=openai))

5. **"Kerr nonlinearity due to intersubband transitions in a three-level InAs/GaAs quantum dot: the impact of a wetting layer on dispersion curves"** (2014): Co-authored with M. Sabaeian, M. Sahrai, and V. Fallahi, this paper explores the Kerr nonlinearity in quantum dots, focusing on the effects of a wetting layer on dispersion curves. ([stanford.academia.edu](https://stanford.academia.edu/AliKhalediNasab?swp=tc-au-6993172&utm_source=openai))

These publications highlight Khaledi Nasab's interdisciplinary research contributions, spanning from theoretical physics to neuroscience and social issues.

Furthermore, Ali Khaledi-Nasab has an academic profile on Google Scholar, indicating a background in physics and astronomy, with publications in areas such as quantum dots and nonlinear dynamics. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Given the commonality of the name, it's possible that the GitHub user @imseyed is a different individual. Without more specific information, I cannot confirm a direct connection between Ali Khaledi Nasab and the GitHub repositories.

task_6.query_used: Search AI conference proceedings and speaker lists for presentations by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_6.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist whose research has spanned various interdisciplinary fields, including nonlinear dynamics, computational neuroscience, and artificial intelligence. His work has been presented at several conferences and has contributed to multiple publications.

**Conference Presentations:**

- **2017 Colloquium at the College of Wooster:** On October 3, 2017, Nasab delivered a colloquium titled "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements" at the Department of Physics at the College of Wooster. His research focused on the stochastic dynamics of tree networks of excitable elements, relevant to certain sensory neurons, such as those in cat muscle spindles. The study aimed to predict the spontaneous activity of these networks by analyzing a single effective node with scaled parameters and suggested mechanisms for tuning the activity of the central element in the tree network. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

- **2019 APS Meeting Presentation:** In March 2019, Nasab presented his paper "Dynamics of excitable tree networks: Application to sensory neurons" at the annual meeting of the American Physical Society (APS) in Boston. His research delved into the dynamical principles of functioning and information processing in sensory neurons with tree-like morphologies of their myelinated terminals, such as those found in muscle spindles, pain receptors, mechanoreceptors, and electroreceptors. The study utilized theoretical and computational approaches to understand mechanisms of spike generation and information coding in these neurons. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

**Publications:**

Nasab has authored and co-authored several publications, including:

- "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements"

- "Variability of collective dynamics in random tree networks of strongly coupled stochastic excitable elements"

- "Information processing in tree networks of excitable elements"

These works explore the collective dynamics and information processing mechanisms in networks of excitable elements, contributing to the understanding of complex systems in neuroscience. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

For a comprehensive overview of his research and publications, you can visit his personal website. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

task_7.query_used: Search corporate filings and business registries for companies associated with Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_7.data:
Based on the available information, there is no direct evidence linking an individual named Ali Khaledi Nasab to specific corporate filings or business registries. However, a search for similar names reveals individuals with the surname "Kharazmi" involved in business activities.

For instance, in the 2016 10-K filing of NuGene International, Inc., the company's Chairman of the Board is Mohammad Ali Kharazmi, and the Acting Chief Financial Officer and Board Member is Mohammad Saeed Kharazmi. The filing discusses a lawsuit involving Advanced Surgical Partners, LLC, which names NuGene, Inc., and the Kharazmi brothers as defendants. ([sec.gov](https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1593549/000161577417001634/s105503_10k.htm?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, the 2006 S-1 filing for U.S. Auto Parts Network, Inc. mentions individuals named Khazani, Nia, and Elyashar, who are associated with the company and its subsidiaries. While the surname differs, the phonetic similarity to "Kharazmi" is notable. ([sec.gov](https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1378950/000119312506221797/ds1.htm?utm_source=openai))

It's important to note that "Kharazmi" is a common surname in Iran, and individuals with this name are involved in various business activities. However, without more specific information, it's challenging to establish a direct connection to an individual named Ali Khaledi Nasab.

task_10.query_used: Search professional networking sites and AI industry forums for Ali Khaledi Nasab mentions
task_10.data:
Ali Khaledi-Nasab is an academic researcher who has contributed to several studies in the fields of physics and software engineering. Notably, he co-authored a paper titled "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge," which explores mechanisms to reduce polarization in social networks by introducing random inputs to users' opinions. ([export.arxiv.org](https://export.arxiv.org/abs/2101.04079?utm_source=openai))

In the software engineering domain, Khaledi-Nasab collaborated on research that involved classifying Stack Overflow posts using machine learning techniques to support software architectural knowledge management. ([onlinelibrary.wiley.com](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpe.6277?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, he co-authored a study titled "Mining Q&A Platforms for Empirical Evidence on Quantum Software Programming," which analyzes discussions on Stack Exchange platforms to identify key topics and challenges in quantum software development. ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/html/2503.05240v1?utm_source=openai))

These publications highlight Khaledi-Nasab's interdisciplinary research interests, spanning social network dynamics and software engineering.

task_11.query_used: Search ORCID and academic identifier databases for Ali Khaledi Nasab research profile
task_11.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist with a diverse academic and professional background. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D. He completed his doctoral studies in Physics and Astronomy at Ohio University, focusing on the dynamics of excitable tree networks in sensory neurons. His research aimed to understand the functioning and information processing in these neurons, which have a tree-like morphology of their myelinated terminals. This work was supervised by Dr. Alexander Neiman, a Professor of Physics at Ohio University. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

After earning his Ph.D., Khaledi Nasab joined the Department of Neurosurgery at Stanford University School of Medicine as a research scientist. There, he worked on developing stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders, including Parkinson's disease. One of the techniques he contributed to is Coordinated Reset (CR) stimulation, which aims to counteract abnormal synchronization in neural networks. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

In 2022, he transitioned to Amazon, where he currently serves as a research scientist in the Network Capacity Planning organization. His work at Amazon focuses on applying his expertise in physics and AI to enhance network performance and capacity. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

Throughout his career, Khaledi Nasab has been involved in various research projects and has contributed to publications in the fields of physics, neuroscience, and AI. His interdisciplinary approach combines principles from nonlinear dynamics, stochastic processes, signal processing, statistics, biophysics, and network sciences. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, he has been active in addressing social issues, such as advocating for international students during the 2017 U.S. travel ban. He authored an article titled "Standing up to fear," published in Science magazine, reflecting on the challenges faced by international students in the U.S. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

For a comprehensive overview of his work and publications, you can visit his personal website. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

task_12.query_used: Search social media platforms (Twitter, Facebook) for accounts and mentions of Ali Khaledi Nasab AI work
task_12.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon Rufus. He holds a Ph.D. in Physics and has a diverse background in physics, neuroscience, and AI. His professional journey includes positions at Stanford University School of Medicine's Department of Neurosurgery and CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup. In 2022, he joined Amazon as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity team. In 2024, he transitioned to Amazon Rufus to work on their latest Generative AI product. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Regarding his presence on social media platforms like Twitter and Facebook, there is no publicly available information indicating that Ali Khaledi Nasab maintains official accounts on these platforms. While there are individuals with similar names on Twitter, such as @hoalimadad, @AliKhalesi8, and @AliKhalesi1, there is no evidence to suggest that these accounts are associated with him. ([idcrawl.com](https://www.idcrawl.com/ali-khalesi?utm_source=openai))

In 2017, Ali Khaledi Nasab authored an article titled "Standing up to fear," published in the journal *Science*. In this piece, he reflects on the challenges faced by international students in the U.S. following the implementation of the travel ban. He discusses the uncertainty and fear experienced by international students and emphasizes the need for institutional support during such times. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

For more detailed information about his professional background and research, you can visit his personal website. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))
